The United Kingdom <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/comprises" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="comprises">comprises</a> the whole of the island of Great Britain—which contains <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/England" class="md-crosslink">England</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Wales" class="md-crosslink">Wales</a>, and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Scotland" class="md-crosslink">Scotland</a>—as well as the northern portion of the island of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Ireland" class="md-crosslink">Ireland</a>. The name <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Great-Britain-island-Europe" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Britain</a> is sometimes used to refer to the United Kingdom as a whole. The capital is <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/London" class="md-crosslink">London</a>, which is among the world’s leading commercial, financial, and cultural centres. Other major cities include <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Birmingham-England" class="md-crosslink">Birmingham</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Liverpool-England" class="md-crosslink">Liverpool</a>, and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Manchester-England" class="md-crosslink">Manchester</a> in England, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Belfast" class="md-crosslink">Belfast</a> and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Londonderry-city-and-district-Northern-Ireland" class="md-crosslink">Londonderry</a> in <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Northern-Ireland" class="md-crosslink">Northern Ireland</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Edinburgh-Scotland" class="md-crosslink">Edinburgh</a> and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Glasgow-Scotland" class="md-crosslink">Glasgow</a> in Scotland, and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Swansea-Wales" class="md-crosslink">Swansea</a> and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Cardiff-Wales" class="md-crosslink">Cardiff</a> in Wales.</p><!--[P1]--><ul class="assemblies medialist" data-type="other"><li><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="3806"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/26/4826-004-4994700F.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/26/4826-004-4994700F.jpg" alt="United Kingdom" data-width="577" data-height="1045"></div></div><figcaption><strong class="md-assembly-title">United Kingdom</strong><span class="md-assembly-caption">United Kingdom</span><cite>Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc.</cite></figcaption></figure></li><li><figure data-type="video" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="194042"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="video"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/35/180135-049-F2A2919C.jpg" alt="London" data-width="426" data-height="240"></div></div><figcaption><strong class="md-assembly-title">London</strong><span class="md-assembly-caption">Take a video tour of London.</span><cite>Contunico © ZDF Enterprises GmbH, Mainz</cite></figcaption></figure></li><li><figure data-type="video" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="186420"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="video"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/24/173124-049-B6BA7356.jpg" alt="London" data-width="426" data-height="240"></div></div><figcaption><strong class="md-assembly-title">London</strong><span class="md-assembly-caption">Time-lapse video of London.</span><cite>Alex Silver</cite></figcaption></figure></li></ul><!--[ML1]--><p>The origins of the United Kingdom can be traced to the time of the Anglo-Saxon king <span id="ref751538"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Athelstan" class="md-crosslink">Athelstan</a>, who in the early 10th century <span class="text-smallcaps">ce</span> secured the <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/allegiance" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="allegiance">allegiance</a> of neighbouring Celtic kingdoms and became “the first to rule what previously many kings shared between them,” in the words of a contemporary chronicle. Through subsequent conquest over the following centuries, kingdoms lying farther afield came under English <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/dominion-British-Commonwealth" class="md-crosslink autoxref">dominion</a>. Wales, a congeries of Celtic kingdoms lying in Great Britain’s southwest, was formally united with England by the Acts of Union of 1536 and 1542. Scotland, ruled from London since 1603, formally was joined with England and Wales in 1707 to form the United Kingdom of Great Britain. (The adjective “British” came into use at this time to refer to all the kingdom’s peoples.) Ireland came under English control during the 1600s and was formally united with Great Britain through the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/Act-of-Union-United-Kingdom-1801" class="md-crosslink">Act of Union</a> of 1800. The republic of Ireland gained its independence in 1922, but six of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Ulster-historic-province-Ireland" class="md-crosslink">Ulster</a>’s nine counties remained part of the United Kingdom as Northern Ireland. Relations between these <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/constituent" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="constituent">constituent</a> states and England have been marked by controversy and, at times, open rebellion and even warfare. These tensions relaxed somewhat during the late 20th century, when devolved assemblies were introduced in Northern Ireland, Scotland, and Wales. Nonetheless, even with the establishment of a power-sharing assembly after referenda in both Northern Ireland and the Irish republic, relations between Northern Ireland’s unionists (who favour continued British <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/sovereignty" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="sovereignty">sovereignty</a> over Northern Ireland) and nationalists (who favour unification with the republic of Ireland) remained tense into the 21st century.</p><!--[P2]--><ul class="assemblies medialist" data-type="other"><li><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="224159"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/84/183784-004-C4A5E9D1.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/84/183784-004-C4A5E9D1.jpg" alt="United Kingdom" data-width="480" data-height="460"></div></div><figcaption><strong class="md-assembly-title">United Kingdom</strong><cite>Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc.</cite></figcaption></figure></li><li><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="96003"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/13/99613-004-31B3604B.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/13/99613-004-31B3604B.jpg" alt="Big Ben, London." data-width="302" data-height="450"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Big Ben, London.</span><cite>© Goodshoot/Jupiterimages</cite></figcaption></figure></li><li><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="223620"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/41/193441-004-F59FCB25.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/41/193441-004-F59FCB25.jpg" alt="British Isles terminology" data-width="675" data-height="675"></div></div><figcaption><strong class="md-assembly-title">British Isles terminology</strong><span class="md-assembly-caption">Terminology for the British Isles, the United Kingdom, Great Britain, and Ireland.</span><cite>Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc./Kenny Chmielewski</cite></figcaption></figure></li></ul><!--[ML2]--><p>The United Kingdom has made significant contributions to the world economy, especially in technology and industry. Since <a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/World-War-II" class="md-crosslink autoxref">World War II</a>, however, the United Kingdom’s most prominent exports have been cultural, including literature, theatre, film, television, and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/art/popular-music" class="md-crosslink autoxref">popular music</a> that draw on all parts of the country. Perhaps Britain’s greatest export has been the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/English-language" class="md-crosslink autoxref">English language</a>, now spoken in every corner of the world as one of the leading international mediums of cultural and economic exchange.</p><!--[P3]--><ul class="assemblies medialist" data-type="other"><li><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="57235"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/12/60112-004-97372343.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/12/60112-004-97372343.jpg" alt="Stonehenge, circular earthwork and stone religious site, Wiltshire, England; late Neolithic Period to Early Bronze Age (1800–1400 bc)." data-width="550" data-height="216"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Stonehenge, circular earthwork and stone religious site, Wiltshire, England; late Neolithic Period to Early Bronze Age (1800–1400 <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span>).</span><cite>Aerofilms Ltd., London</cite></figcaption></figure></li><li><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="24057"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/27/1927-004-308BD790.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/27/1927-004-308BD790.jpg" alt="Ravenscraig Castle, Kirkcaldy, Scotland." data-width="356" data-height="300"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Ravenscraig Castle, Kirkcaldy, Scotland.</span><cite>Malcolm Fife/The Edinburgh Photographic Library</cite></figcaption></figure></li></ul><!--[ML3]--><p>The United Kingdom retains links with parts of its former empire through the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Commonwealth-association-of-states" class="md-crosslink">Commonwealth</a>. It also benefits from historical and cultural links with the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/United-States" class="md-crosslink autoxref">United States</a> and is a member of the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/North-Atlantic-Treaty-Organization" class="md-crosslink">North Atlantic Treaty Organization</a> (NATO). Moreover, the United Kingdom became a member of the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/European-Union" class="md-crosslink">European Union</a> in 1973. Many Britons, however, were sometimes reluctant EU members, holding to the <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/sentiments" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="sentiments">sentiments</a> of the great wartime <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/prime-minister" class="md-crosslink autoxref">prime minister</a> <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Winston-Churchill" class="md-crosslink">Winston Churchill</a>, who sonorously remarked, “We see nothing but good and hope in a richer, freer, more contented European commonalty. But we have our own dream and our own task. We are with Europe, but not of it. We are linked, but not <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/comprised" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="comprised">comprised</a>. We are interested and associated, but not absorbed.” Indeed, in June 2016, in a referendum on whether the United Kingdom should remain in the EU, 52 percent of British voters chose to leave. That set the stage for the U.K. to become the first country to do so, pending the negotiations between the U.K. and the EU on the details of the separation.</p><!--[P4]--></section><span class="md-signature"><a href="/contributor/Ralph-Charles-Atkins/3481">Ralph Charles Atkins</a></span><span class="md-signature"><a href="/editor/The-Editors-of-Encyclopaedia-Britannica/4419">The Editors of Encyclopaedia Britannica</a></span><!--[H2]--><section id="ref44671" data-level="1"><h2 class="h1"><span id="ref484135"></span>Land</h2><p>The United Kingdom comprises four geographic and historical parts—<a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/England" class="md-crosslink">England</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Scotland" class="md-crosslink">Scotland</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Wales" class="md-crosslink">Wales</a>, and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Northern-Ireland" class="md-crosslink">Northern Ireland</a>. The United Kingdom contains most of the area and population of the British Isles—the geographic term for the group of islands that includes Great Britain, Ireland, and many smaller islands. Together England, Wales, and Scotland <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/constitute" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="constitute">constitute</a> Great Britain, the larger of the two principal islands, while Northern Ireland and the republic of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Ireland" class="md-crosslink">Ireland</a> constitute the second largest island, Ireland. England, occupying most of southern Great Britain, includes the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Isles-of-Scilly-islands-England-United-Kingdom" class="md-crosslink">Isles of Scilly</a> off the southwest coast and the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Isle-of-Wight" class="md-crosslink">Isle of Wight</a> off the southern coast. Scotland, occupying northern Great Britain, includes the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Orkney-Islands" class="md-crosslink">Orkney</a> and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Shetland-Islands-Scotland" class="md-crosslink">Shetland</a> islands off the northern coast and the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Hebrides" class="md-crosslink">Hebrides</a> off the northwestern coast. Wales lies west of England and includes the island of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Isle-of-Anglesey" class="md-crosslink">Anglesey</a> to the northwest.</p><!--[P5]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="15244"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/07/20307-004-44AEB441.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/07/20307-004-44AEB441.jpg" alt="Windermere, Cumbria, England" data-width="499" data-height="300"></div></div><figcaption><strong class="md-assembly-title">Windermere, Cumbria, England</strong><span class="md-assembly-caption">Windermere, Cumbria, England.</span><cite>Julie Fryer/Bruce Coleman Ltd.</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML5]--><p>Apart from the land border with the Irish republic, the United Kingdom is surrounded by sea. To the south of England and between the United Kingdom and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/France" class="md-crosslink autoxref">France</a> is the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/English-Channel" class="md-crosslink">English Channel</a>. The <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/North-Sea" class="md-crosslink">North Sea</a> lies to the east. To the west of Wales and northern England and to the southeast of Northern Ireland, the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Irish-Sea" class="md-crosslink">Irish Sea</a> separates Great Britain from Ireland, while southwestern England, the northwestern coast of Northern Ireland, and western Scotland face the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Atlantic-Ocean" class="md-crosslink">Atlantic Ocean</a>. At its widest the United Kingdom is 300 miles (500 km) across. From the northern tip of Scotland to the southern coast of England, it is about 600 miles (1,000 km). No part is more than 75 miles (120 km) from the sea. The capital, London, is situated on the tidal <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/River-Thames" class="md-crosslink">River Thames</a> in southeastern England.</p><!--[P6]--><p>The archipelago formed by <span id="ref484134"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Great-Britain-island-Europe" class="md-crosslink">Great Britain</a> and the numerous smaller islands is as irregular in shape as it is <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/diverse" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="diverse">diverse</a> in geology and landscape. This <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/diversity" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="diversity">diversity</a> stems largely from the nature and <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/disposition" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="disposition">disposition</a> of the underlying rocks, which are westward extensions of European structures, with the shallow waters of the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Strait-of-Dover" class="md-crosslink">Strait of Dover</a> and the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/North-Sea" class="md-crosslink">North Sea</a> concealing former land links. Northern Ireland contains a westward extension of the rock structures of Scotland. These common rock structures are <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/breached" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="breached">breached</a> by the narrow <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/North-Channel-strait" class="md-crosslink">North Channel</a>.</p><!--[P7]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="13249"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/19/25419-004-F1E2CCD1.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/19/25419-004-F1E2CCD1.jpg" alt="The North Channel coast south of Torr Head, Northern Ireland" data-width="254" data-height="300"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">The North Channel coast south of Torr Head, Northern Ireland</span><cite>© Michael Jennet/Robert Harding Picture Library</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML7]--><p>On a global scale, this natural endowment covers a small area—approximating that of the U.S. state of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Oregon-state" class="md-crosslink">Oregon</a> or the African country of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Guinea" class="md-crosslink">Guinea</a>—and its internal diversity, accompanied by rapid changes of often beautiful scenery, may convey to visitors from larger countries a striking sense of compactness and consolidation. The peoples who, over the centuries, have hewed an existence from this Atlantic extremity of Eurasia have put their own imprint on the <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/environment" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="environment">environment</a>, and the ancient and distinctive palimpsest of their field patterns and settlements complements the natural diversity.</p><!--[P8]--><section id="ref44672" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2">Relief</h2><p>Great Britain is traditionally divided into a highland and a lowland zone. A <span id="ref484136"></span>line running from the mouth of the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/River-Exe" class="md-crosslink autoxref">River Exe</a>, in the southwest, to that of the Tees, in the northeast, is a crude expression of this division. The course of the 700-foot (213-metre) <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/contour" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="contour">contour</a>, or of the boundary separating the older rocks of the north and west from the younger southeastern strata, provides a more accurate indication of the extent of the highlands.</p><!--[P9]--></section></section><nav class="prev-next-pagination The Roman numeral II is unnecessary here, as the arms of Elizabeth I were different, apart from those of England. The shield shows England (in heraldic terms gules three leopards or) quartered with Scotland (or a lion rampant within a double tressure flory counterflory gules) and Ireland (azure a harp or stringed argent). This is the quartering in use since the accession of Queen Victoria in 1837. The shield is encircled by the garter of the Order of the Garter bearing the motto of the order, “Honi soit qui mal y pense” (“Evil to him who evil thinks”). The dexter supporter, a royally crowned gold lion guardant, and the sinister supporter, a silver unicorn with gold horn, hooves, mane, and tufts and a gold coronet collar and chain, represent England and Scotland, respectively. Atop the full-faced helm of a sovereign with its ermine and gold mantling, or lambrequin, is the royal crown surmounted by the royal crest, a lion statant guardant crowned with the royal crown. The motto “Dieu et mon droit” (“God and my right”), first used by Richard I, appears on the scroll below. The ground beneath the full achievement, called the compartment, is strewn with the floral and plant badges of England (rose), Scotland (thistle), Ireland (shamrock), and Wales (leek)."
